document.title: The theorem of F. and M. Riesz

para.p:

Moreover, the total order
≤

We say that
G
with the total order induced by
P
is a totally ordered group. We shall use the following lemma in the next section. 1 footnote 1 1 footnote 1 Walter Rudin, Fourier Analysis on Groups, p. 194, Theorem 8.1.2.

p.text:
Suppose that
Γ
is a discrete abelian group.
Γ
can be totally ordered if and only if
∈ γ Γ
having finite order implies that
= γ 0
.

para.p:
If
G
is a compact abelian group, then
G
is connected if and only if
∈ γ
^ G
having finite order implies that
= γ 0
. 2 footnote 2 2 footnote 2 Walter Rudin, Fourier Analysis on Groups, p. 47, Theorem 2.5.6. Combined with Lemma , we get that a compact abelian group is connected if and only if its dual group can be ordered.

Suppose in the rest of this section that
G
is a connected compact abelian group, and let
≤

The above lemma is used to prove the following theorem. 5 footnote 5 5 footnote 5 Walter Rudin, Fourier Analysis on Groups, p. 200, Theorem 8.2.3. The proof of this theorem in Rudin is not long, but I don’t understand the first step in his proof so I have not attempted to write it out.

p.text:
Suppose that
G
is a connected compact abelian group and that
∈ μ

is

section.title: 3The theorem of F. and M. Riesz

para.p: We are now equipped to prove the theorem of F. and M. Riesz. 6 footnote 6 6 footnote 6 Walter Rudin, Fourier Analysis on Groups, p. 201, §8.2.4.

p.text:
If
∈ μ
⁢ M
( T )
and
=
⁢
^ μ
( n )
0
for every negative integer
n
, then
μ
is absolutely continuous with respect to Haar measure.
